messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 22, 2020 - July 28, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-07-30T14:41:04Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-07-22T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-07-28T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200730-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs. 

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2020-07-25T00:00Z-03:00Z and 2020-07-25T21:00Z-24:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a S-type (<500 km/s) CME around 2020-07-24T00:18Z. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-07-29T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-08-04T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate.  There are several active regions present on the solar disk as seen on the available imagery.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the possible arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-08-03.   

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 15, 2020 - July 21, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-07-22T22:13:57Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-07-15T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-07-21T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200722-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low level during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=2 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-07-22T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-07-28T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a diffuse coronal hole high speed stream around 2002-07-23 and a possible disturbance on or near 2002-07-24 from an S-type (<500 km/s) CME that was first visible in STEREO A coronagraph on 2020-07-19T09:36Z. 

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 08, 2020 - July 14, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-07-15T21:51:14Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-07-08T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-07-14T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200715-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.      

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2020-07-14T00:00Z-09:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the possible arrival detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 of a combination of a small coronal high speed stream and an S-type (<500 km/s) CME around 2020-07-13.  

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-07-15T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-07-21T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2002-07-22.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 01, 2020 - July 07, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-07-08T20:22:28Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-07-01T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-07-07T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200708-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=3 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2020-07-01T21:00Z-24:00Z, 2020-07-04T18:00Z-24:00Z, 2020-07-05T03:00Z-12:00Z and 2020-07-05T21:00Z-24:00Z.  The minor increase in geomagnetic activity on 2020-07-04 and 2020-07-05 was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2020-07-04. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2020-07-05T17:24Z     ~505            C               -32/-7                20                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 
## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-07-08T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-07-14T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming reporting period.  There are no significant active regions present on the solar surface as seen on the available imagery.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-07-14.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score
